The Latest Technology Wins

Using Cookieless ID to Curb Paywall Hopping

CUSTOMER DATA

  • How Paywalls Work Today: The paywall system currently uses an msmp cookie, known as a sampling cookie. This cookie is not tied to any user ID and tracks how many articles a user consumes. A hard paywall is triggered once the user exceeds the limit set by the campaign.

  • The Problem: Paywall Circumvention: Many users bypass paywalls by going incognito or clearing their cookies, allowing them to continue reading beyond the limit without hitting the paywall again.

  • The Solution: A new service called VisitIQ will use Fingerprint IDs generated using an API partner for cookieless ID. IDs will be generated for consenting visitors to TNY US to track article consumption in a database instead of cookies. Because Fingerprint IDs are cookieless and more resilient, they prevent users from hopping paywalls by deleting cookies or browsing incognito.

  • Results and Next Steps: 5% of fingerprinted visitors exhibited paywall hopping behavior during testing. Despite this, mobile conversions increased by 47% and desktop conversions by 39%, adding an estimated $934k in annual revenue. Plans are underway to expand this approach to other brands like BA, Wired, and VF to reduce revenue loss due to hopping behavior.

Unifying Data with Single Customer View

CUSTOMER DATA

  • Knowing Our Customer: Single Customer View (SCV) aims to create a complete, unified profile of each customer by combining both known and anonymous data from online and offline interactions.

  • How We Build a Unified View: The process involves accurately identifying customers across multiple touchpoints and merging various identifiers. A master ID is created for users interacting with any of our brandsâ€”whether they visit our site, click an affiliate link, or subscribe to a magazine.

  • Whatâ€™s Included in the SCV: The MVP (minimum viable product) of SCV provides an aggregated view of each user that includes unified revenue contributions from subscriptions (consumer), affiliate commerce (consumer), and ad revenue (commercial) and engagement metrics like email opens/clicks and time spent on the site. Data is available by brand and time frames like the last 30, 60, or 90 days.

  • Whatâ€™s Next: SCV helps the data science team build customer archetypes for personalized monetization and dynamic experiences. The next step is to add more identifiers and attributes, enriching SCV for advanced use cases like paid media segmentation.

Experimentation with GrowthBookâ€™s Visual Editor

CUSTOMER DATA

  • Experimentation Highlights So Far: Since March, our product experimentation platform, GrowthBook, has powered over 50 experiments across teams, enabling data-driven insights that shape our products. With this platform, weâ€™ve taken a leap towards creating products backed by solid data.

This equips teams to run faster, more agile testing cycles, giving PMs and designers more control over experimentation.

  • Whatâ€™s Next: Next steps include rolling out server-side implementation for complex experiments and integrating results reporting and program metrics into GrowthBook. Reach out the experiments team for access and/or support.

Consent or Pay on AD Germany

REVENUE

  • What â€œConsent or Payâ€ Means: AD Germany is testing a new model where users either consent to cookies for tracking and personalized ads or pay a small subscription fee to access content without cookies. This replaces the option to reject all cookies entirely.

  • Why this Change Matters: With up to 40% of users in EU markets rejecting cookies, this test aims to recover the lost opportunity (such as lower ad revenue) by offering a subscription alternative for those who prefer not to share their data.

  • What We Did: The â€œConsent or Payâ€ test was launched in just 6 weeks, showcasing incredible teamwork between several teams across the markets. AD Germany is the first to roll out this approach, marking a significant shift in how we tackle cookie consent challenges.

  • What We Learned from the Launch: In the first few weeks since we launched, weâ€™ve managed to increase our cookie consent rate from 60% to 93%, whilst keeping bounce rate relatively flat (i.e. negligible negative impact).

  • Whatâ€™s Next: Visit ad-magazin.de to see the new consent banner and subscription checkout flow in action. This test will help determine future strategies around cookie consent and revenue recovery across other EU markets.

Revamped Payment Flow Drives Subscriptions

REVENUE

  • Payment Flow Testing: We tested a redesigned payment experience on Architectural Digest in September that showed promising results with a smoother debit/credit card process and better user interface that boosted subscriptions and revenue compared to our control.

  • Check-out Results: The new flow achieved a 12% increase in subscriptions, an 11% rise in net new revenue, and a 13% improvement in order form conversion rate. Quantuum Metrics also provided insights into optimizing the email and review steps for further gains.

  • Expanding Success: This week, Payment Flow 2.0 rolls out on The New Yorker, with ongoing analysis planned to refine and optimize the payment process across titles.
